(HIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY*S GOVERNMENTPrinted for the Cabinet. January 1946.SECRET.C,p. (46) 23.0 January, 1946.CABINET.MONTHLY DIGEST OF STATISTICS.Note by the Lord President.WHEN the White Paper giving "Statistics relating to the War Effort ofthe United Kingdom " (Cmd. 6564) was issued in November, 1944, it was statedin the Introduction that further information would be released as soon as cir-cumstances permitted.2. When the war ended in Europe all Departments were pressed to liftthe statistical black-out and to resume the regular publication of statistics relatingto the economic activity of the country. These demands came from the businessworld, the Universities and the responsible Press.3. In July, 1945, when the Caretaker Government were in office, the lord presidents Committee decided, after considering a memorandum by the thenChancellor of the Exchequer (L.P. (45) 122), that in order to meet these demands (i) Departments should review their arrangements for the publication of statistics in the light of the new situation brought about by the endof the war in Europe and should aim at publishing as much statistical information as possible; and(ii) The Central Statistical Office, in consultation with the Departments con-cerned, should prepare for monthly publication a summary of theprincipal economic statistics of the United Kingdom on the lines ofthe existing Statistical Digest, Series "B" (L.P. (45) 126thConclusions, Minute 4).4. Since this decision was taken, the war with Japan had ended and Depart-ments have been gradually releasing more statistical information. A considerableamount of detailed statistical information is now being regularly published inthe Board of Trade Journal, the Ministry of Labour Gazette, the Trade and navigation A ccounts, and other official publications.5. At the same time the Central Statistical Office, on the instructions of theLord Presidents Committee, have been discussing with Departments whatstatistics should be included in a regular monthly Digest which would not only[31209]Copy No.^ give a selection of the more important statistics already being published by departments but would also include such additional information as Departmentsdesired to release.6. When these discussions with Departments had been completed theproposal to publish a monthly Digest was resubmitted to the Lord presidents committee, who, at their meeting on the 11th January, 1946 (L.P. (46) 1st Comelusions, Minute 3), authorised the Chancellor of the Exchequer to publish, as aStationery Office publication, "a monthly report giving a summary statement ofthe principal economic statistics of the United Kingdom."7. The contents of the Digest have now been finally approved by theDepartments concerned, and the first volume in the series has been prepared for publication.At the Prime Ministers request I circulate the attached proof to the CabinetI think it right that we should make available in a convenient form the statistical information needed to provide a background for an informed under-standing of Government policy; and I am confident that the publication of thisDigest will be well received by responsible opinion throughout the country. \hope, therefore, that the Cabinet will find no difficulty in authorising publication.H. M.Great George Street, S. W. 1,25th January, 1946. CENTRAL STATISTICAL OFFICEMONTHLY DIGESTOFSTATISTICSNo. january 1946LONDON: HIS MAJESTY'S STATIONERY office price 2s. 6d. NET
MONTHLY DIGEST OF STATISTICSNo. I. JANUARY 8946I. Introductory NotesTh;s Digest,which will be published monthiy, has been prepared by the Central Statistical Office in collabora-tion with the Statistics Divisions of Government Departments. The Departments and organisations responsiblefor providing each series of statistics are stated underneath each table.The aim is to publish in summary form statistics which show the changing pattern of the economic activity of the country. All the statistics are, therefore, presented in the form of time series. Figures are given, so faras possible, for each of the calendar years 1935 to 1944, and monthly since the beginning of. 1944.The scope of the Digest will be revised from time to time to include new statistical information as it becomes available. Many of the series appearing in the Digest are given in greater detail in other official publications.In particular, reference should be made to the Board of Trade Journal, the Ministry of Labour Gazette, and theTrade and Navigation Accounts, where some of the statistics given in this Digest appear regularly in greater detail.II. General NotesI. A Supplement has been prepared giving in detail the definitions of the items and units employed in thisDigest. Copies of this Supplement can be obtained from H.M. Stationery Office (price 6d.). There are, however,a number of points of general importance which should be borne in mind.2. Consumption. Figures of consumption particularly should be used with caution. Changes in con-sumption from month to month may be explained by seasonal factors. Figures given under the headings of"consumption " or " disposals " are usually derived from statistics of releases from stocks by Controls or manu-facturers, and include the amount delivered for export. Where exports form a significant proportion of totaldisposals, however, the amount made available for consumption within the United Kingdom is shown separately in the tables.3. Stocks. Figures of stocks should also be used with caution, since changes in stocks from month to monthmay likewise be explained by seasonal factors. Moreover, figures of stocks often relate to only part of the total stocks in the country. The definitions of figures of stocks are given either in footnotes to each table, or in more detail in the Supplement to this Digest.4. Figures of stocks relate either to the end of a calendar month or to the end of a four or five weekly period.Where the information for this date cannot be obtained the figures relate to the date nearest to the end of themonth for which figures are available. If this date is more than seven days from the end of the month the day ofthe month is stated in a footnote. .t,5. Area covered. Except where otherwise stated, all statistics relate to the United Kingdom of GreatBritain and Northern Ireland.6. Revisions. Some of the figures included in this Digest are regarded by Departments as provisional only and may be revised in later issues. Each issue contains all the revisions made in the figures up to the date of publication of the Digest.7. Symbols employed. The following symbols have been used throughout the Digest : .. = not available = nil or less than half the final digit shown* = average of five weeksG.T. ^ gross tonsD.W. = deadweight tons 8. Where necessary, each figure has been rounded off to the nearest final digit. For this reason there maybe in some tables an apparent slight discrepancy between the sum of the constituent items and the total as shown.9. A line drawn across a column between two consecutive figures indicates that the figures above and belowthe line have been compiled on different bases and are not strictly comparable. In each case a footnote is addedindicating the nature of the difference.Central Statistical Office,Great George Street, S.W.I. -^January, 1946.8374 contents. Railways) were increased by 5%. In the case of workmen's fares, afractions rule was imposed so as to avoid increases in fares below 5d.2) On llth June, 1939, local fares of Main Line Railways in the London area were increased by 5%. Fares on the Board's Railways, were revised with theobject of removing anomalies and discrepancies and bringing them nearerIt to a uniform standard of Id. per mile.J) On 1st May, 1940, charges for passengers were increased by 10%, both on the MainLines and on the Board's Railways. On 3rd July, 1940, ordinary fares on theBoard's Railways were raised as follows : Id. fare increased to l^d., I d.fare increased to 2d.
